<anchor type="collate" xml:id="C07"/><milestone n="1" type="start" unit="chapter"/> <head> CHAPTER I.
<anchor type="collate" xml:id="C07"/><milestone n="1" type="start" unit="chapter"/> <head> CHAPTER I.
The passionate and almost reverential attachment with which all regarded her became, while I shared it, my pride and my delight. On
evening previous to her being brought to my home, my mother
said playfully,—“I have a pretty present for my Victor—to-morrow he shall have it.” And when, on the morrow, she presented Elizabeth
me as her promised gift, I, with childish seriousness, interpreted
as mine—mine to protect, love, and cherish. All praises bestowed on her,

received as made to a possession of my own. We called each other familiarly by the name of cousin. No word, no expression could body forth the kind of relation in which she stood to me—my more than sister, since till death she was to be mine only.

myself. I have described myself as always having been embued with a fervent longing to penetrate the secrets of nature. In spite of the intense labour
always came from my studies discontented and unsatisfied. Sir Isaac Newton is said
have avowed that he felt like a child picking up shells beside the great and unexplored ocean of truth. Those of his successors in each branch
natural philosophy with whom I was acquainted, appeared even
The untaught peasant beheld the elements around him, and was acquainted with their practical uses. The most learned philosopher knew little more. He had partially unveiled the face
her immortal lineaments were still a wonder and a mystery. He might dissect, anatomise, and give names; but,
to speak of a final cause, causes
tertiary grades were utterly unknown to him.
had gazed upon the fortifications and impediments that seemed
keep human beings from entering the citadel of nature, and rashly and ignorantly I had repined.
But here were books, and here were men who had penetrated deeper and knew more. I took their word for all that they averred, and I became their disciple.
while I followed the routine of education in the schools of Geneva, I was, to a great degree, self taught with regard to my favourite studies. My father
was left to struggle with a child’s blindness, added to a student’s thirst for knowledge. Under the guidance of my new preceptors,
